Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2011 08:58AM roseamy wrote: Hi, I had mx followed by rads I did have very bad radiation burn which left the chest muscle (as my surgeon said) like concrete. 15 months later I had an ld flap with implant done, then to fill in a couple of dips I had fat grafting, this not only softened the area and improved the cosmetic look but it also improved the radiotherapied skin. I have since had this done again and the feel of the muscle and skin is again improved. THe surgeon has said this has improved the capsular contracture I have and I have noticed an improvement in the look of the surface of the skin, prior to this it was very thin and firm. He did say to me when I saw him last that he fully expects to be removing implants from Ladies like me and replacing them with fat grafts (c cup) in about 5 to 10 years time, but at the moment the rate a which they could remove and treat the stem cells from the fat collected would take too long but things are moving rapidly in this area of reconsrution. I am in England by the way. Rose
Posts.Title: Fat Graft Transfer and the Radiated Breast whippetmom dancetrancer

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 01:43PM roseamy wrote: Hi Gillovski,  I did not have ultrasound on my remaining breast but on my liver and abdomen to check for spread due to pain on right side under ribs. this came back clear, I had previosly had a ct scan and bone scan due to this pain and these also came back clear these where ordered by my onco who I was seeing every 3 months at the time. if your Gp has not had your previous notes( may not have access to them from abroad) they will not know about your diagnosis. I would bring them up to date that way they will get you on breast screen programme which is every 3 years(over 47), regardless of whether you have had breast cancer or not. I think some areas within ten years of diagnosis will offer either annual or biannual mammos then after that if still under 47 biannual or over 47 every 3 years. When you go for your mammogram inform the breast clinic of your diagnosis so this is on their notes as well. My self referral is because I am only 2 1/2 years from diagnosis and still under the hospitals care, also they will only bone scan you if they suspect secondary spread this is not done routinely here. Good luck.
Posts.Title: UK Mammograms every 5 yrs - Unbelievable gillovski hymil

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2011 02:25PM roseamy wrote: Hi, i can only answer for my area of britain ; here they give mammograms routinely every 3 years age 47 and over. Since my dx I had a mammogram at the 1 year point which will be followed by one at 3 year point, 5 year point, 7 years and 9 years, then onto national screening programme. If you are still under 47 then you get them every 2 years till then. I also have an open appointment with my breast clinic so I can ring at any time and self refer, this also applies with my oncology dept. As for scans they do not over scan here possibly because of the way we are funded by the NHS, I had bone and ct scans at dx due to local advanced bc, then again last year when I had pain on right side, I have had xrays and an ultra sound scan this year ordered by my GP again for rightsided pain, luckily so far nothing has shown up. I was not sent to a breast clinic when I was 36 having found a lump, told it was a fibroadeanome ( GP did not follow NICE guidelines) was dx at 40. Changed Gp's which probably saved my life. I have been quite happy with all my treatment and have never been refused any drugs or treatment and all is going really well.
Posts.Title: UK Mammograms every 5 yrs - Unbelievable gillovski hymil

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 03:30PM roseamy wrote: Hi,  I also had an ooph by chioce at 42, also dx at 40. Was on tamox but periods returned with avengence so onco said he would start goserlin injections as strongly er+ and pr+, my reply "I have no need for my ovaries, 3 kids don't think I want any more how about you whip them out?" he said "ok I agree". 6 weeks later they where out now on arimidex. Gynea also agreed best decision for me, do I miss them NO!! okay there is downsides to no oestrogen-- hot flushes, joint pain etc but hell I'm alive.
Posts.Title: Never hearing the word Cured!!!! faithfulheart jennifer1

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 02:47PM roseamy wrote: Hi, i had mine removed june 10 after 18 mths my periods returned my onc wanted to stop the production of oestrogen as I am strongly er/pr+ he was going to use zoladex, but I asked for my ovaries to be removed instead.  I have 3 teens and had been on tamox for 12 months, he agreed to this straight away. After seeing the gynea he also agreed this was the best decision for me, I was already having hot flushes etc and these have continued i am now just 43 and on arimidex. For me this was the best solution.
Posts.Title: What are the reasons for taking out ovaries? geogal nikola

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2011 05:28AM roseamy wrote: Hi, mamita49  i am stage 3b with no nodes due to skin involvement. polyana i was dx 2008 I was told I had a 70% chance of living another 10 years and my surgeon is very confident that all will be well, as of today I am ned for 2 years and doing fine. I did not have a period for 18 months then they came back. I was only 40,I have since had a bilat salpingooopherectomy due to 100% er+ pr+, so you may not be post menopausal yet. I was on tamox when they came back. good luck.
Posts.Title: How long will i survive stage 3B Polyana SpunkyGirl

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2012 11:47AM roseamy wrote: Hi, I have had a few scares scares, 1. pain in right rib and spine area worse at night--- bone scan negative, possible pulled muscle. 2.severe pain in liver area and swelling-- blood tests and ultrasound -- negative, probable viral infection or gall stone. 3. chain of swollen lymph nodes from collar bone to behind ear--ct scan negative, infection and lymph nodes reacting took a few months to go down due to weak immune system. 4. Lump in breast over original tumour site-- radiation damage caused implant to be squeezed capsular contraction, clear on ultrasound. surgeon more worried than me and wanted urgent scan. All this with in 3 years of diagnosis, my onco and breast surgeon both said I will have scares and to tell them and they will deal with it. Chances are they will be nothing. I just think enjoy life I am still here and doing well and what will be will be and get on with living and enjoying every moment.
Posts.Title: Scares anyone can share that turned out to be nothing? fondak fondak

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 01:12PM roseamy wrote: Hi Nannababy, I too was classed as locally advanced with no nodes 5cm tumor as I had skin involment, I had neo adj chemo and when I had the mx was then down to a  t2nomo. I am also still considered as locally advanced because that is how I first presented and was treated as such.
Posts.Title: T3N1M0 is locally advanced or early stage? Nevo84 kathleen1966

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 12:57PM roseamy wrote: I had skin involvement this was where the tumour (mixed ilc/ idc) had started to fix/extend itself into the skin, it had not broken through and when I had my mx they removed a lot more skin than normal. I am 2 years ned. good luck
